docs.title: VC From Noise
docs.text:
Vertex Color From Noise

Create Vertex Colors from Generated Noise.

docs.title: Modifier Parameters
docs.text:
• Noise Scale: Controls the scale of the base noise octave.
  • Noise Detail: Determines the number of noise octaves. It can accept fractional values, which results in a blend between the two integer values.
  • Noise Roughness: Allows you to blend between a smoother noise pattern and a rougher one with sharper peaks.
  • Noise Lacunarity: Defines the difference in scale between consecutive octaves. Higher values result in a larger scale for higher octaves.
  • Noise Distortion: Controls the amount of distortion applied to the noise.
  • Noise Contrast: Adjusts the value range between light and dark areas.

docs.title: Mix & Mask
docs.text:
Mix & Mask Parameters

These settings are present on nearly all Vertex Colors Kit Modifiers.

docs.title: Mix
docs.text:
Color Mix Settings

  • Blend Mode: Changes how colors are mixed.
    • Mix: A standard linear blend, or 'lerp', between the two colors.
    • Darken: Takes the darkest value of each color channel.
    • Multiply: Multiplies the color values.
    • Color Burn: A darker, more saturated result than Multiply.
    • Lighten: Takes the lightest value of each color channel.
    • Screen: A lighter result than Add.
    • Color Dodge: A brighter, more saturated result than Screen.
    • Add: Adds the color values together.
    • Overlay: A combination of Multiply and Screen.
    • Soft Light: Softer version of Overlay.
    • Linear Light: A combination of Color Dodge and Color Burn.
    • Difference: Subtracts the top layer from the bottom layer.
    • Exclusion: Similar to Difference, but with lower contrast.
    • Subtract: Subtracts the color values.
    • Divide: Divides the color values.
    • Hue: Uses the hue of the top layer and the saturation and value of the bottom layer.
    • Saturation: Uses the saturation of the top layer and the hue and value of the bottom layer.
    • Color: Uses the hue and saturation of the top layer and the value of the bottom layer.
    • Value: Uses the value of the top layer and the hue and saturation of the bottom layer.
  • Blend Factor: Controls the strength of the blend.
  • Switch Blend Order: Swaps the input colors, altering the blend result.

docs.title: Mask
docs.text:
Attribute and Channel Mask Settings

  • Attribute Mask: Uses a custom attribute to mask the effect.
  • Invert Mask: Inverts the influence of the attribute mask.
  • R Channel: Adjusts the influence of the Red channel.
  • G Channel: Adjusts the influence of the Green channel.
  • B Channel: Adjusts the influence of the Blue channel.
  • A Channel: Adjusts the influence of the Alpha channel.

docs.title: VC Preview
docs.text:
Vertex Color Preview

Previews the selected Vertex Color channels in the 3D viewport.

docs.title: Modifier Parameters
docs.text:
• Unlit Material: Toggles an unlit material to view the colors without scene lighting influence.
  • R Channel: Toggles the visibility of the Red channel.
  • B Channel: Toggles the visibility of the Blue channel.
  • G Channel: Toggles the visibility of the Green channel.
  • A Channel: Toggles the visibility of the Alpha channel.

Warning

This modifier temporarily overrides the mesh's materials for preview purposes. If left enabled on export or applied to the mesh, this override will be baked into the final result. Disable or remove it to restore your original materials.

docs.title: VC To UV
docs.text:
Vertex Color To UV

Stores Vertex Color data into one or two UV maps.

docs.title: Modifier Parameters
docs.text:
• VC UV 1 Name: Sets the name of the first UV map to store color data in.
  • VC UV 2 Name: Sets the name of the second UV map to store color data in.

Channel Packing

By default, the RG channels are sent to the first UV map (VCUV1) and the BA channels are sent to the second (VCUV2).

docs.title: VC To Vertex Group
docs.text:
Vertex Color To Vertex Group

Converts Vertex Color data into a weight-painted Vertex Group.

docs.title: Modifier Parameters
docs.text:
• Vertex Group: The Vertex Group to write the weight data to.

Mix & Mask Parameters

Refer to the Mix & Mask page for a full description of these settings.

Weight Painting

A primary use for this modifier is to create complex weight maps non-destructively. By generating procedural vertex colors with other modifiers in the kit, you can create intricate weight patterns that would be difficult to paint by hand.

Note that Vertex Groups store a single float value (0.0 to 1.0) for weight. To convert, the incoming Vertex Color is first desaturated to a grayscale value which is then used as the weight.

Existing Vertex Group Required

The name provided must match your target Vertex Group exactly. If the name doesn't match or the group doesn't exist, a new data Attribute will be created instead of writing to the Vertex Group. It is highly recommended to create your target Vertex Group before using this modifier.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Vertex Color Kit is a collection of Geometry Node modifiers installed via Blender's Asset Library.

docs.title: Installation Steps
docs.text:
1. Download and Extract Download the latest VertexColorKit.zip file. Extract the entire contents of the zip file to a permanent location on your computer where you plan to keep your assets.

  2. Open Blender Preferences Launch Blender and navigate to the preferences window by selecting Edit > Preferences.

  3. Add Asset Library In the Preferences window, go to the File Paths tab. Find the Asset Libraries section and click the + button to add a new library path.

  4. Select the Folder Blender will open a file browser. Navigate to the folder where you just extracted the VertexColorKit files, select it, and click the Add Asset Library button.

  5. Save and Restart Save your preferences by clicking the button in the bottom-left of the Preferences window. You must restart Blender for the asset library to be fully loaded. s

docs.title: Accessing the Modifiers
docs.text:
After restarting Blender, open the Asset Browser. You will find all the modifiers under the "Vertex Color Kit" category. Simply drag and drop them from the Asset Browser onto your mesh object.

Official Documentation

For more detailed information on how Blender's Asset Library works, you can refer to the Official Blender Manual.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common solutions for issues you may encounter while using the Vertex Color Kit.

docs.title: "The modifiers aren't doing anything!"
docs.text:
Since Vertex Colors aren't visible in the viewport by default, it can be difficult to see the effect of the modifiers.

Solution

It is highly recommended to add and pin the VC Preview modifier to your stack first before adding any others. This allows you to see the changes from other modifiers in real-time.

docs.title: "I have too many modifiers!"
docs.text:
Working with many geometry node modifiers can make the default modifier stack difficult to navigate.

Solution

For managing large and complex modifier stacks, we recommend using the Modifier List addon for Blender. It provides a more compact and organized view of your modifiers.

docs.title: "I can't see my vertex colors in Solid Shading mode!"
docs.text:
To view Vertex Colors in the 'Solid' viewport shading mode, you need to change how objects are colored by default.

Solution

  1. In the top-right of the 3D Viewport, click the dropdown arrow for Viewport Shading.
  2. Under the Color options, change the mode from Material to Attribute.

Your mesh will now display the active Vertex Color layer instead of its material color.

docs.title: "I can't see my mesh!"
docs.text:
A key feature of the Vertex Color Kit is that the Alpha channel is treated just like the RGB channels. If a modifier clears the Alpha channel to zero, your mesh may become invisible.

Solution

In the VC Preview modifier, toggle the visibility of the A Channel off to prevent the mesh from vanishing.

docs.title: "I can't see the vertex color alpha channel in Solid Shading mode!"
docs.text:
Blender's 'Solid' viewport shading mode does not support displaying attribute alpha.

Solution

Switch to Material Preview or Rendered shading modes to see the alpha channel's effect.

Alternatively, for a quick preview, add a VC Swizzle modifier to the bottom of the stack to visualize the Alpha channel in the R, G, or B channels. Remember to disable it when you're done to avoid overwriting your color data.

docs.title: "My materials are gone!"
docs.text:
This typically happens if the VC Preview modifier is still active on your object.

Solution

The VC Preview modifier temporarily overrides the mesh's materials for preview purposes. To restore your original materials, simply disable or remove the modifier from your stack. Always remove it before exporting to prevent the material override from being baked into the final result.
